Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: AToL: PorToL - The Porifera Tree of Life Project
Award.AbstractNarration:
Last Modified Date: 07/08/08 Last Modified By: Richard M. McCourt

Abstract
A grant has been awarded to the University of Alabama at Birmingham under the direction of Dr. Robert W. Thacker for assembling the phylogenetic tree of sponges. Sponges are an ancient animal group with simple body construction. They are extremely efficient at filtering bacteria and other small food particles from the water in which they live, with thousands of different sponge species found in the world's oceans and freshwater habitats. Along with their important ecological roles, sponges can yield potential new medicines and host an extraordinary diversity of microbial life. Despite their widespread presence in aquatic habitats, the study of sponges has lagged behind that of other more charismatic marine fauna. Sponges pose special difficulties for those interested in deciphering their taxonomy, classification, and evolutionary relationships because sponge bodies are quite plastic, varying from one individual to the next. These difficulties hamper progress in basic studies of sponge biology and biodiversity, including comparative studies aimed at understanding the evolution of animals and efforts to conserve or economically exploit aquatic ecosystems. Using molecular genetic data from 8,000 sponge specimens, this project will provide a phylogenetic context that will improve the understanding of all aspects of sponge biology.

Proper Incorporation of sponges in the Tree of Life is imperative, because there is wide consensus that sponges comprise the primary trunk leading to more complex animals. Data from this project will test this hypothesis and resolve many "branches" within the sponge tree of life. This project will assist communication and collaboration within the international sponge research community by creating an internet-accessible database. This project will provide numerous outreach and educational opportunities, including undergraduate and graduate student training, intensive field courses, professional workshops, and conference symposia. This project benefits society as a whole by helping to track the origin and distribution of crucial genes (and chemical markers) that are useful in medicine and industry and by establishing new model systems for the study of early animal evolution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sponges belong to an ancient metazoan lineage with a fossil record that stretches back more than 600 Myr ago. As a sister group (or groups) to all the other animals in the metazoan tree of life, sponges represent a fulcrum point in the history of animal life lying at the junction between single-celled ancestors and the rest of Metazoa. Sponges have also been important ecosystem engineers throughout much of their history, e.g., as major reef-builders during the Upper Devonian, Upper Permian, and through a major portion of the Jurassic. In modern oceans, poriferans continue to perform important ecological functions as water filterers, bioeroders, structural habitat providers, microbial symbiont incubators, dissolved organic carbon sinks, natural product biosynthesizers, chemical accumulators, and potential marine pathogen reservoirs. As one of the most diverse taxa of extant sessile invertebrates, a detailed exploration of poriferan evolutionary relationships promises to yield important insights into many phases of metazoan history. For example, the origin of tissue, sensory cells, and cell-to-cell gap junctions all likely occured in the organisms that gave rise to modern-day sponges.

Despite their importance, sponges are notoriously difficult to taxonomically classify, and taxonomic controversy extends from the highest levels of classification (e.g., whether the phylum Porifera is monophyletic) to whether particular genera belong to one or another family. As currently envisioned, four classes comprise the phylum Porifera: Calcarea = (Calcispongiae plus the fossil group Heteractinida), Demospongiae, Homoscleromorpha, and Hexactinellida. Our goal with this research was to clarify some of the relationships within and among these lineages.

The Porifera Tree of Life (PorToL) project (www.portol.org) employed a variety of tools to integrate morphological and molecular data, and to expand the diversity of sponge taxa used to elucidate all levels of sponge phylogeny. Our goal was to provide insights into some of the most difficult questions in metazoan systematics. In one paper, for example, based on a significant expansion of samples (38 new samples representing 30 families, including 21 families newly sampled), we used nuclear housekeeping genes isolated from each species, with a thorough taxonomic vetting process and a slightly modified phylogenetic analysis, to focus on relationships within Demospongiae (Hill et al. 2013). Our understanding of phylogenetic relationships within the phylum Porifera has changed considerably with increased taxon sampling and data from additional molecular markers. PorToL researchers have falsified earlier phylogenetic hypotheses, supported others, discovered novel phylogenetic alliances, found phylogenetic homes for enigmatic taxa, and provided a more precise understanding of the evolution of skeletal features, secondary metabolites, body organization, and symbioses (Thacker et al. 2013). At the 2013 annual SICB meeting, the PorToL team presented a series of symposium papers and contributed talks to address progress toward these goals and to test hypotheses of relationships among sponges. Some of these exciting discoveries are shared in the papers that form a special issue of Integrative and Comparative Biology (Vol 53, Issue 3). In addition, species new to science were discovered and described during this research (e.g., Friday et al. 2013 - see accompanying figure).

In addition to a number of important contributions to the scientific literature, we also trained a large number of students through this project. At the University of Richmond, more than 15 undergraduates took part in the research. Many of these students are now graduate students in prestigious institutions around the world (e.g., Duke, MIT, Standford, Australian Institute of Marine Science, Washington University of St. Louis, Stony Brook, UVA).
